title: Diabetes
intro: Why is the disease diabetes on the rise? Alice and Neil talk about the role that diet and exercise have to play in this global health problem – and whether Neil eats too much processed food.
this_week_question: How many people in the world suffer from diabetes? Is it…
You'll hear the answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: a condition where the body can't control the amount of glucose in the blood
food that has been changed from its natural state, for example, by freezing or dehydrating it, or by adding ingredients to it such as sugar, salt or fat
the growth of towns and cities as people move there from the countryside to live and work
something that changes slowly over time
a point when small changes become significant enough to cause a big change

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … And I'm Neil. Can you pass me my drink, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Cola, Neil? That's very unhealthy.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You told me to stop drinking coffee because it's unhealthy – now you're telling me cola is bad too.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Cola is full of sugar. There are about six teaspoons in each can.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: At least. That's pretty sugary, I admit!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, we're talking about diabetes today. Diabetes is a condition where the body can't control the amount of glucose – or sugar – in the blood. If left untreated, diabetes can cause many complications, including heart attack, stroke, kidney failure, and blindness. Neil I'm not diabetic, though, Alice, so what's the problem?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, diabetes is on the rise – or increasing – all over the world. And particularly type 2 diabetes where risk factors include obesity – or being very overweight – unhealthy diet and lack of physical exercise.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I see. Well, while I think about that, maybe you could ask me today's quiz question.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: OK. Can you tell me how many people in the world suffer from diabetes? Is it… a) 4.15 million? b) 41.5 million? Or c) 415 million?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'll take a guess and say b) 41.5 million.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out if you got the right answer later on, Neil. Now, why do you think people are eating less healthily than they used to?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, processed food has become very popular, and whilst it often tastes really good, it isn't always a healthy choice.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Do you eat a lot of processed food, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Of course not, Alice! Processed food , by the way, is food that's been changed from its natural state, for example, by freezing or re-hydrating it, or by adding ingredients to it such as sugar, salt or fat. But let's move on now and talk about exercise.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: OK – but I hope you aren't planning to have fried chicken again for lunch today from that dodgy fast-food joint round the corner. Now, one reason that people are taking less exercise than they used to is because of lifestyle changes. With increasing urbanisation people are no longer doing jobs that involve as much physical activity.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, it's true. And urbanisation means the growth of towns and cities as people move there from the countryside to live and work. We're all sitting in cars, and offices, or on our sofas in front of the TV.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: But it's also true that children are less active than they used to be. I remember running around all the time outdoors when I was a kid. Nowadays, they're all in front of screens, playing computer games or watching videos on YouTube.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, adults and children are at higher risk of developing diabetes if they are overweight because they are likely to have higher levels of sugar in their blood. Let's hear more about this from Dr Etienne Krug from the World Health Organization.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Etienne Krug, Director of the World Health Organization Diabetes is a kind of continuum. Gradually the levels of sugar in the blood increase until reaching the level of being diagnosed with diabetes. But people, before reaching diabetes, have too high level of sugar as well, sometimes, and that can be dangerous too – particularly causing cardiovascular diseases, which contributes to mortality too.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What's a continuum , Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It's something that changes slowly over time. So in this case, as people increasingly eat food that's high in sugar and fat, the amount of sugar in their blood increases.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And having a high blood-sugar level may reach a tipping point – or a point when small changes become significant enough to cause a big change – and you develop diabetes. But even if you don't develop diabetes, high blood sugar can be damaging to your health.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It isn't only damaging to the individual, though. Diabetes has a huge cost to society – $827bn is currently being spent every year to treat the disease.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's big bucks! What can we do – what can governments do – to tackle this health crisis, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, a key approach is to tackle the global rise in obesity because this addresses not only diabetes but other diseases, too, such as cancer and cardiovascular disease. Let's hear more from Dr Krug about ways to do this.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Etienne Krug, Director of the World Health Organization We need a combination of approaches to promote physical activity and to improve the ways we eat and that goes from breast feeding or even working with young kids to increase healthy eating. But the sugar tax is a good example that has contributed in Mexico to a decrease in sales of sugary drinks. And sugary drinks – just one drink can sometimes represent more sugar than a person needs for the whole day.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Government schemes to encourage healthy eating sound like a good plan, but trying to get kids to eat vegetables might be tough!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Or stop you from drinking sugary drinks, Neil, for that matter.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Leave me alone!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright, then. But the government tax on sugary drinks has worked in Mexico – and the UK government is also planning to do this. OK – now remember I asked you, Neil: How many people in the world suffer from diabetes? Is it… a) 4.15 million? b) 41.5 million? Or c) 415 million?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said 41.5 million.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Sorry, that's the wrong answer, Neil. Neil Of course it's the wrong answer! Alice Yes, I'm afraid so. According to the Diabetes International Federation, based in Belgium, as of 2015, an estimated 415 million people have diabetes worldwide. This represents 8.3% of the adult population, with equal rates in both women and men.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, I'll be drinking herbal tea from now on. Let's listen to the words we learned today. They were: diabetes glucose on the rise obesity processed food urbanisation continuum tipping point

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon!

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
